docs.lead_paragraph: A group of former Allstate agents are looking for their day in court after waiving their right to bring a lawsuit. They said they had no choice but to sign.

headline.main: Allstate Case Shows Risk of Signing Away the Right to Sue
headline.print_headline: Allstate Case Shows Risk of Signing Away the Right to Sue

docs.abstract: Group of former Allstate agents are waiting for their day in court, thirteen years after signing release waiving their right to sue when insurance company cut off their benefits and forced them to become independent contractors; 31 agents have sued anyway, insisting waivers are invalid because they were forced to sign; case, which has been delayed multiple times, illustrates challenges employees face when deciding to sue employers.
docs.snippet: A group of former Allstate agents are looking for their day in court after waiving their right to bring a lawsuit. They said they had no choice but to sign.

docs.lead_paragraph: Logistics will be complicated as more than 14,000 pieces of artwork, worth hundreds of millions of dollars, are transported through Manhattan.

headline.main: For the Whitney’s Move, Boxes and Burly Men Just Won’t Do
headline.print_headline: For the Whitney’s Move, Boxes and Burly Men Just Won’t Do

docs.abstract: Whitney Museum is facing daunting logistics as it contemplates move from its Upper East Side home at Madison and 75th Street to Gansevoort and Washington Streets in meatpacking district; move is scheduled to begin in late October and should be completed for spring opening.
docs.snippet: Logistics will be complicated as more than 14,000 pieces of artwork, worth hundreds of millions of dollars, are transported through Manhattan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Groups independent of the likely nominees in Colorado's Senate race are running ads that question the motives of the candidates, adding millions to what outside groups are already spending on negative television spots six months before Election Day.

headline.main: Enviro Group's Ad Criticizes Gardner in Colo. Race
headline.print_headline: Enviro Group's Ad Criticizes Gardner in Colo. Race

docs.snippet: Groups independent of the likely nominees in Colorado's Senate race are running ads that question the motives of the candidates, adding millions to what outside groups are already spending on negative television spots six months before Election Day.

docs.lead_paragraph: Express Scripts reported a 12 percent drop in its first-quarter earnings Tuesday, saying its prescription sales were hit by severe winter weather and slower-than-expected enrollment in the new public insurance exchanges.

headline.main: Express Scripts Profit Falls in 1Q on Lower Sales
headline.print_headline: Express Scripts Profit Falls in 1Q on Lower Sales

docs.snippet: Express Scripts reported a 12 percent drop in its first-quarter earnings Tuesday, saying its prescription sales were hit by severe winter weather and slower-than-expected enrollment in the new public insurance exchanges.

docs.lead_paragraph: Deciding which party controls the Senate for the final two years of President Barack Obama's tenure could come down to women — both the handful who are running in significant races and the moderate female voters who often make the difference in close elections.

headline.main: Women Candidates, Voters Could Decide Senate
headline.print_headline: Women Candidates, Voters Could Decide Senate

headline.main: Baseball, Happiness and Immigration: Exploring American Society and History With New York Times Maps

docs.abstract: In this lesson we surface some of our favorite United States maps in The New York Times. We also offer strategies to help students use careful observation and analysis to make sense of these data-rich maps so they can learn more about our current society, history and geography.

docs.lead_paragraph: The House approved bipartisan legislation Tuesday to exempt U.S. health plans sold to expatriate workers from having to comply with requirements under the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: House Passes Bipartisan Fix to Health Law
headline.print_headline: House Passes Bipartisan Fix to Health Law

docs.snippet: The House approved bipartisan legislation Tuesday to exempt U.S. health plans sold to expatriate workers from having to comply with requirements under the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: No Comment Necessary: Scott Brown's Take on 'Obamacare'

docs.abstract: He thinks it’s disastrous, but seems to like everything it does.
docs.snippet: He thinks it’s disastrous, but seems to like everything it does.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has begun a wide-ranging search for companies to run the online federal health insurance exchange to prevent a repeat of the site’s problems from last fall.

headline.main: Administration Begins Search for New Contractors to Run Health Care Site
headline.print_headline: Administration Begins Search for New Contractors to Run Health Care Site

docs.abstract: Obama administration begins wide-ranging search for companies to run online federal health insurance exchange, seeking new talent to prevent a repeat of problems that immobilized the website in 2013.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration has begun a wide-ranging search for companies to run the online federal health insurance exchange to prevent a repeat of the site’s problems from last fall.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The State University of New York has been trying to sell the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, but state officials are having second thoughts about the possible developers.

headline.main: Reconsidering the Saviors of a Hospital
headline.print_headline: Reconsidering the Saviors of a Hospital

docs.abstract: Michael Powell Gotham column examines ongoing efforts of State University of New York to sell Long Island College Hospital in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; notes that state officials are having second thoughts about front-running candidate for development of property, Brooklyn Health Partners, which turns out to have no experience developing anything as remotely complicated as a hospital.
docs.snippet: The State University of New York has been trying to sell the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, but state officials are having second thoughts about the possible developers.
